message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Agent-Based Modeling in Economics and Finance: Past, Present, and Future
Paper Abstract: Agent-based modeling (ABM) is a novel computational methodology for representing the behavior of individuals in order to study social phenomena. Its use is rapidly growing in many fields. We review ABM in economics and finance and highlight how it can be used to relax conventional assumptions in standard economic models. ABM has enriched our understanding of markets, industrial organization, labor, macro, development, public policy, and environmental economics. In financial markets, substantial accomplishments include understanding clustered volatility, market impact, systemic risk, and housing markets. We present a vision for how ABMs might be used in the future to build more realistic models of the economy and review some of hurdles that must be overcome to achieve this. (JEL C63, D00, E00, G00)
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of macroeconomics:

## Definition

Macroeconomics is a branch of economics that deals with the performance, structure, behavior, and decision-making of an economy as a whole, including regional, national, and global economies.

## Key Areas of Study

Macroeconomists study aggregate measures of the economy, such as output or gross domestic product (GDP), national income, unemployment, inflation, consumption, saving, investment, or trade.(no content)The three central macroeconomic variables are output, unemployment, and inflation.

## Relationship to Microeconomics

Macroeconomists focus on large-scale phenomena, or aggregate variables, and differ significantly from microeconomists who study the principle-agent problem at a smaller level of analysis—either firms or consumers.

## Time Horizons

Macroeconomics is divided into topics depending on the time frame of analysis: short-term fluctuations over the business cycle, medium-term determinants of aggregate variables like unemployment, unaffected by short term shocks, and long-term economic growth.

## Historical Development

Macroeconomics as a separate field of research and study is generally recognized to start in 1936, when John Maynard Keynes published his The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money.

Macroeconomics is a branch of economics that deals with the performance, structure, behavior, and decision-making of an economy as a whole, including regional, national, and global economies.

## Key Areas of Study

Macroeconomists study aggregate measures of the economy, such as output or gross domestic product (GDP), national income, unemployment, inflation, consumption, saving, investment, or trade.(no content)The three central macroeconomic variables are output, unemployment, and inflation.

## Relationship to Microeconomics

Macroeconomists focus on large-scale phenomena, or aggregate variables, and differ significantly from microeconomists who study the principle-agent problem at a smaller level of analysis—either firms or consumers.

## Time Horizons

Macroeconomics is divided into topics depending on the time frame of analysis: short-term fluctuations over the business cycle, medium-term determinants of aggregate variables like unemployment, unaffected by short term shocks, and long-term economic growth.

## Historical Development

Macroeconomics as a separate field of research and study is generally recognized to start in 1936, when John Maynard Keynes published his The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of finance and economics:

## Financial Economics

Financial economics is the branch of economics characterized by a "concentration on monetary activities", in which "money of one type or another is likely to appear on both sides of a trade".(no content)Its concern is the interrelation of financial variables, such as share prices, interest rates and exchange rates, as opposed to those concerning the real economy.(no content)Financial economics has two main areas of focus: asset pricing and corporate finance; the first being the perspective of providers of capital (investors), and the second of users of capital.

## Key Concepts

Financial economics studies how rational investors would apply decision theory to investment management, and is built on the foundations of microeconomics.(no content)The questions addressed in financial economics models are typically framed in terms of "time, uncertainty, options, and information".

## Related Fields

Public finance refers to the monetary resources available to governments and also to the study of finance within government and role of the government in the economy.(no content)In finance and economics, interest is payment from a debtor or deposit-taking financial institution to a lender or depositor of an amount above repayment of the principal sum, at a particular rate.

I've completed a web search for "Financial market" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key results:

## Definition and Overview

A financial market is a market in which people trade financial securities and derivatives at low transaction costs.(no content)Some of the securities include stocks and bonds, raw materials and precious metals, which are known in the financial markets as commodities.

## Types of Financial Markets

Financial markets encompass several categories:

- Stock markets, which provide financing through the issuance of shares or common stock, and enable the subsequent trading thereof.
- Bond markets, which provide financing through the issuance of bonds, and enable the subsequent trading thereof.
- Commodity markets, which facilitate trading in the primary economic sector rather than manufactured products.
- Money markets, which provide short term debt financing and investment; Derivatives markets, which provide instruments for the management of financial risk; Foreign exchange markets, which facilitate the trading of foreign exchange; and Cryptocurrency markets, which facilitate the trading of digital assets and financial technologies.

## Primary and Secondary Markets

Newly formed (issued) securities are bought or sold in primary markets, such as during initial public offerings.(no content)Secondary markets allow investors to buy and sell existing securities.

## Purpose and Function

Financial markets attract funds from investors and channels them to corporations—they thus allow corporations to finance their operations and achieve growth.

Web search results for query: "Industrial organization economics"

Links: [{"title":"Industrial organization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_organization"},{"title":"Joe Bain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Bain"},{"title":"Luís Cabral (economist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luis_Cabral_(economist)"},{"title":"Yingyao Hu - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yingyao_Hu"},{"title":"Richard Friberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Friberg"},{"title":"Stephen Salant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Salant"},{"title":"Richard M. Burton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_M._Burton"},{"title":"Michael Whinston - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Whinston"},{"title":"Steven L. Heston - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steven_L._Heston"},{"title":"Industrial Economics Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Economics_Institute"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of industrial organization economics:

## Definition and Scope

Industrial organization is a field in economics that extends the theory of the firm by analyzing the structure of firms and markets, as well as the boundaries between them.(no content)It introduces real-world features that depart from the perfectly competitive model, such as transaction costs and imperfect competition.

## Key Approaches

The field employs multiple approaches. One approach is descriptive in providing an overview of industrial organization, such as measures of competition and the size-concentration of firms in an industry.(no content)A second approach uses microeconomic models to explain internal firm organization and market strategy, which includes internal research and development along with issues of internal reorganization and renewal.(no content)A third aspect is oriented to public policy related to economic regulation, antitrust law, and the economic governance of law in defining property rights, enforcing contracts, and providing organizational infrastructure.

## Foundational Work

Joe S. Bain developed the influential structure–conduct–performance (SCP) paradigm, which examines the relationships among market structure, firm behavior, and economic performance, and pioneered the empirical analysis of barriers to entry, market concentration, and profitability as indicators of market power.

## Modern Tools and Impact

The extensive use of game theory in industrial economics has led to the export of this tool to other branches of microeconomics, such as behavioral economics and corporate finance. Additionally, industrial organization has had significant practical impacts on antitrust law and competition policy.

Here are the search results for **Computational Economics**:

## Overview

Computational or algorithmic economics is an interdisciplinary field combining computer science and economics to efficiently solve computationally-expensive problems in economics.(no content)Some areas are unique, while others are established areas of economics that benefit from robust data analytics and solutions of problems that would be arduous to research without computers and associated numerical methods.

## Key Areas and Advances

Major advances in computational economics include search and matching theory, game theory, the theory of linear programming, algorithmic mechanism design, and fair division algorithms.(no content)Innovative approaches such as machine learning models and agent-based modeling have been actively explored in different areas of economic research, offering economists an expanded toolkit that frequently differs in character from traditional methods.

## Agent-Based Computational Economics (ACE)

Agent-based computational economics (ACE) is the area of computational economics that studies economic processes, including whole economies, as dynamic systems of interacting agents.(no content)ACE models apply numerical methods of analysis to computer-based simulations of complex dynamic problems, and starting from initial conditions specified by the modeler, the computational economy evolves over time as its constituent agents repeatedly interact with each other, including learning from interactions.

## Applications

The subject has been applied to research areas like asset pricing, energy systems, competition and collaboration, transaction costs, market structure and industrial organization and dynamics, welfare economics, and mechanism design, information and uncertainty, macroeconomics, and Marxist economics.

## Tools and Languages

C++ performs the fastest as a compiled language, while Python is the slowest as an interpreted language, with MATLAB, Julia, and R achieving a balance between performance and interpretability.

Links: [{"title":"Labour economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_economics"},{"title":"Journal of Labor Economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Labor_Economics"},{"title":"IZA Institute of Labor Economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IZA_Institute_of_Labor_Economics"},{"title":"Labour Economics (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Economics_(journal)"},{"title":"Category:Labour economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Labour_economics"},{"title":"Henry Farber - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Farber"},{"title":"Category:Labor economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Labor_economics"},{"title":"The labor problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_labor_problem"},{"title":"Labor theory of value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_theory_of_value"},{"title":"Research in Labor Economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_in_Labor_Economics"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of labor economics:

## Definition and Scope

Labour economics is the subfield of economics concerned with the study of labour as an input to economic production, and broadly surveys labor markets and the economic decisions of agents participating in such markets.

## Key Areas of Study

Labor economics covers various aspects including supply and demand of labor services, personnel economics, distribution of income, unions and collective bargaining, and labor markets and demographics.

## Labor Market Dynamics

Neoclassical economists view the labour market as similar to other markets in that the forces of supply and demand jointly determine the price (in this case the wage rate) and quantity (in this case the number of people employed). However, the labour market differs from other markets in several ways, and in particular may act as a non-clearing market—while most markets quickly reach equilibrium, the labour market may have a persistent level of unemployment.

## Employment Concepts

The labour force is defined as the number of people of working age, who are either employed or actively looking for work (unemployed).(no content)The natural rate of unemployment (also known as full employment) is the summation of frictional and structural unemployment, and is the lowest rate of unemployment that a stable economy can expect to achieve.

## Academic Institutions and Publications

Labor economics is supported by various research institutions and journals. Labour Economics is a bimonthly peer-reviewed academic journal covering labor economics, established in 1993 as the official journal of the European Association of Labour Economists.

Epstein - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua_M._Epstein"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"}]

## Agent-Based Modeling

Here's comprehensive information about agent-based modeling based on the search results:

### Definition and Core Concept

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.(no content)Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena through emergence, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts, and higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

### Key Characteristics

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.(no content)Individual agents are typically characterized as boundedly rational, presumed to be acting in what they perceive as their own interests, such as reproduction, economic benefit, or social status, using heuristics or simple decision-making rules.

### Implementation

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

### Historical Development

The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s, and since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

### Applications

Agent-based modeling has diverse applications across multiple fields including biology, ecology, economics, social sciences, and urban planning. Agent-based models can be used to simulate a wide variety of social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts.

## Agent-Based Modeling

Here's comprehensive information about agent-based modeling based on the search results:

### Definition and Core Concept

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.(no content)Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena through emergence, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts, and higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

### Key Characteristics

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.(no content)Individual agents are typically characterized as boundedly rational, presumed to be acting in what they perceive as their own interests, such as reproduction, economic benefit, or social status, using heuristics or simple decision-making rules.

### Implementation

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

### Historical Development

The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s, and since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

### Applications

Agent-based modeling has diverse applications across multiple fields including biology, ecology, economics, social sciences, and urban planning. Agent-based models can be used to simulate a wide variety of social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts.

Web search results for query: "Development economics"

Links: [{"title":"Development economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_economics"},{"title":"Economic development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_development"},{"title":"Human development (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_development_(economics)"},{"title":"Category:Development economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Development_economics"},{"title":"Michael Todaro - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Todaro"},{"title":"Review of Development Economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Review_of_Development_Economics"},{"title":"Journal of Development Economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Development_Economics"},{"title":"Category:Development economists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Development_economists"},{"title":"Developmentalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developmentalism"},{"title":"Talk:Development economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Development_economics"}]

## Development Economics

Development economics is a branch of economics that deals with economic aspects of the development process in low- and middle-income countries.(no content)Its focus is not only on methods of promoting economic development, economic growth and structural change but also on improving the potential for the mass of the population, for example, through health, education and workplace conditions, whether through public or private channels.

### Key Focus Areas

Development economics involves the creation of theories and methods that aid in the determination of policies and practices and can be implemented at either the domestic or international level. This may involve restructuring market incentives or using mathematical methods such as intertemporal optimization for project analysis, or it may involve a mixture of quantitative and qualitative methods.(no content)Common topics include growth theory, poverty and inequality, human capital, and institutions.

### Approach and Methods

Unlike in many other fields of economics, approaches in development economics may incorporate social and political factors to devise particular plans.(no content)It recognizes the necessity of treating the problems of development and underdevelopment from an institutional and structural (noneconomic) as well as an economic perspective, with appropriate modifications of received general economic principles, theories, and policies.

### Historical Background

The earliest Western theory of development economics was mercantilism, which developed in the 17th century, paralleling the rise of the nation state.(no content)From the 1940s to the 1960s the state played a large role in promoting industrialization in developing countries, following the idea of modernization theory. This period was followed by a brief period of basic needs development focusing on human capital development and redistribution in the 1970s. Neoliberalism emerged in the 1980s pushing an agenda of free trade and removal of import substitution industrialization policies.

Web search results for query: "Environmental economics"

Links: [{"title":"Environmental economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_economics"},{"title":"Ecological economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_economics"},{"title":"Economics for Equity and the Environment Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics_for_Equity_and_the_Environment_Network"},{"title":"Category:Environmental economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Environmental_economics"},{"title":"Natural resource economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_resource_economics"},{"title":"Association of Environmental and Resource Economists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_Environmental_and_Resource_Economists"},{"title":"Category:Environmental economists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Environmental_economists"},{"title":"Bounded rationality in environmental decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_rationality_in_environmental_decision_making"},{"title":"Natural resource valuation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_resource_valuation"},{"title":"Environmental policy of the Biden administration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_Joe_Biden_administration"}]

Here are the search results for "Environmental economics":

## Overview

Environmental economics "undertakes theoretical or empirical studies of the economic effects of national or local environmental policies around the world."(no content)It has become a widely studied subject due to growing environmental concerns in the twenty-first century.

## Key Concepts

Central to environmental economics is the concept of market failure.(no content)Environmental economics focuses on the efficient allocation of natural resources in order to fulfill human wants.

## Historical Development

Although the term "environmental economics" became popular beginning in the 1960s, the entwinement of the two fields of environmentalism and economics started much earlier.(no content)Starting with economist Marquis de Condorcet in the 18th century, who had an interest in the link between economic activity and environmental issues.

## Distinction from Ecological Economics

Ecological economics takes a more holistic approach to traditional economic theories, while environmental economics fits within traditional economic theories. Ecological economists emphasize "strong" sustainability and reject the proposition that human-made capital can substitute for natural capital, while environmental economics focuses on the efficient allocation of natural resources in order to fulfill human wants.

## Professional Organizations

The Association of Environmental and Resource Economists (AERE) was founded in 1979 in the United States as a means of exchanging ideas, stimulating research, and promoting graduate training in environmental and natural resource economics.(no content)AERE is generally acknowledged as the primary professional organization for Environmental and Natural Resources economists in the USA.

Links: [{"title":"Housing market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Housing_market"},{"title":"Australian property market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_property_market"},{"title":"Canadian property bubble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_property_bubble"},{"title":"California housing shortage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_housing_shortage"},{"title":"2000s United States housing bubble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000s_United_States_housing_bubble"},{"title":"Subprime mortgage crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subprime_mortgage_crisis"},{"title":"Housing affordability in anglophone countries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_housing_markets_by_real_estate_prices"},{"title":"Real estate economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_estate_economics"},{"title":"2008 financial crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007–2008_financial_crisis"},{"title":"The Big Short (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Big_Short_(film)"}]

I've completed a web search for "Housing market" and retrieved comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

The housing market refers to the economics of real-estate used for residential purposes, as well as the real estate business of buying, selling, or renting real estate.

## Market Characteristics

The housing market means the supply and demand for houses, usually in a particular country or region. Housing market includes features such as supply of housing, demand for housing, house prices, rented sector and government intervention in the housing market.

## Recent Global Trends

**Australia:** The residential housing market has seen drastic changes in prices in recent decades, with property prices soaring in major cities like Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth, Brisbane and Hobart.

**Canada:** The housing market experienced a brief slowdown during the onset of the pandemic, but the Bank of Canada slashed interest rates and reduced mortgage stress test rates, enabling prices to soon rebound.

**United States:** Since about 1970, California has been experiencing an extended and increasing housing shortage, estimated to be 3-4 million housing units as of 2017.

Links: [{"title":"Volatility (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volatility_(finance)"},{"title":"VIX - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VIX"},{"title":"2025 stock market crash - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_stock_market_crash"},{"title":"Equity premium puzzle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equity_premium_puzzle"},{"title":"Saudi Exchange - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi_Exchange"},{"title":"Robert J. Shiller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Excess_volatility_puzzle"},{"title":"2015–2016 stock market selloff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015-16_stock_market_selloff"},{"title":"Technical analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technical_trading"},{"title":"Inverse exchange-traded fund - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_etf"},{"title":"Stock market index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_market_index"}]

Here are the search results for "Stock market volatility":

## Definition and Measurement

In finance, volatility is the degree of variation of a trading price series over time, usually measured by the standard deviation of logarithmic returns. There are two main types: Historic volatility measures a time series of past market prices, while implied volatility looks forward in time, being derived from the market price of a market-traded derivative (in particular, an option).

## The VIX - Market Volatility Index

The VIX is the Chicago Board Options Exchange's CBOE Volatility Index, a popular measure of the stock market's expectation of volatility based on S&P 500 index options, calculated and disseminated on a real-time basis by the CBOE, and is often referred to as the fear index or fear gauge.(no content)The current VIX index value quotes the expected annualized change in the S&P 500 index over the following 30 days, as computed from options-based theory and current options-market data.

## Recent Market Volatility

Recent events have demonstrated significant market volatility. Starting on April 2, 2025, global stock markets crashed amid increased volatility following the introduction of new tariff policies by U.S. president Donald Trump, with the announcement triggering widespread panic selling across global stock markets and becoming the largest global market decline since the 2020 stock market crash.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Systemic risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systemic_risk"},{"title":"Systematic risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_risk"},{"title":"Financial Stability Oversight Council - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_Stability_Oversight_Council"},{"title":"Systemic Risk Council - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systemic_Risk_Council"},{"title":"Category:Systemic risk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systemic_risk"},{"title":"Risk factor (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_factor_(finance)"},{"title":"Networked-loan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked-loan"},{"title":"Sheri Markose - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheri_Markose"},{"title":"European Systemic Risk Board - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Systemic_Risk_Board"},{"title":"Large and complex financial institutions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_and_complex_financial_institutions"}]

I've completed the web search for "Systemic risk financial." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Concept

In finance, systemic risk is the risk of collapse of an entire financial system or entire market, as opposed to the risk associated with any one individual entity, group or component of a system, that can be contained therein without harming the entire system.

## How Systemic Risk Spreads

As depositors sense the ripple effects of default, and liquidity concerns cascade through money markets, a panic can spread through a market, with a sudden flight to quality, creating many sellers but few buyers for illiquid assets.

## Regulatory Framework

Governments and market monitoring institutions (such as the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and central banks) often try to put policies and rules in place with the justification of safeguarding the interests of the market as a whole.(no content)In simple English, this means that some companies are viewed as too big and too interconnected to fail.

## Assessment Metrics

According to the Property Casualty Insurers Association of America, there are two key assessments for measuring systemic risk, the "too big to fail" (TBTF) and the "too (inter)connected to fail" (TCTF or TICTF) tests.

The search results also covered regulatory bodies like the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) and international oversight groups established to monitor and mitigate systemic financial risks.

Web search results for query: "Public policy"

Links: [{"title":"Public policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_policy"},{"title":"Public policy of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_policy_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"National Center for Public Policy Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Center_for_Public_Policy_Research"},{"title":"Institute for Public Policy Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_Public_Policy_Research"},{"title":"Public Policy Institute of California - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Policy_Institute_of_California"},{"title":"Ethics and Public Policy Center - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_and_Public_Policy_Center"},{"title":"Master of Public Policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_of_Public_Policy"},{"title":"List of public policy topics by country - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_policy_topics_by_country"},{"title":"Goldman School of Public Policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldman_School_of_Public_Policy"},{"title":"Category:Public policy in Australia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Public_policy_in_Australia"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about public policy:

## Definition

Public policy is an institutionalized proposal or a decided set of elements like laws, regulations, guidelines, and actions to solve or address relevant and problematic social issues, guided by a conception and often implemented by programs.

## Scope and Coverage

These policies govern and include various aspects of life such as education, health care, employment, finance, economics, transportation, and all over elements of society.

## Creation and Implementation

They are created and/or enacted on behalf of the public, typically by a government. However, sometimes they are made by Non-state actors or are made in co-production with communities or citizens, which can include potential experts, scientists, engineers and stakeholders or scientific data.(no content)The implementation of public policy is known as public administration.

## Policy Process

A popular way of understanding and engaging in public policy is through a series of stages known as "the policy cycle", which was first discussed by the political scientist Harold Laswell in his book The Decision Process: Seven Categories of Functional Analysis, published in 1956. The characterization of particular stages can vary, but a basic sequence is agenda setting, policy formulation, legitimation, implementation, and evaluation.

## Actors Involved

The policy process is a complex political process in which there are many actors: elected politicians, political party leaders, pressure groups, civil servants, publicly employed professionals, judges, non-governmental organizations, international agencies, academic experts, journalists and even sometimes citizens who see themselves as the passive recipients of policy.

Links: [{"title":"Public policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_policy"},{"title":"Public policy of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_policy_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"National Center for Public Policy Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Center_for_Public_Policy_Research"},{"title":"Institute for Public Policy Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_Public_Policy_Research"},{"title":"Public Policy Institute of California - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Policy_Institute_of_California"},{"title":"Ethics and Public Policy Center - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_and_Public_Policy_Center"},{"title":"Master of Public Policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_of_Public_Policy"},{"title":"List of public policy topics by country - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_policy_topics_by_country"},{"title":"Goldman School of Public Policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldman_School_of_Public_Policy"},{"title":"Category:Public policy in Australia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Public_policy_in_Australia"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about public policy:

## Definition

Public policy is an institutionalized proposal or a decided set of elements like laws, regulations, guidelines, and actions to solve or address relevant and problematic social issues, guided by a conception and often implemented by programs.

## Scope and Coverage

These policies govern and include various aspects of life such as education, health care, employment, finance, economics, transportation, and all over elements of society.

## Creation and Implementation

They are created and/or enacted on behalf of the public, typically by a government. However, sometimes they are made by Non-state actors or are made in co-production with communities or citizens, which can include potential experts, scientists, engineers and stakeholders or scientific data.(no content)The implementation of public policy is known as public administration.

## Policy Process

A popular way of understanding and engaging in public policy is through a series of stages known as "the policy cycle", which was first discussed by the political scientist Harold Laswell in his book The Decision Process: Seven Categories of Functional Analysis, published in 1956. The characterization of particular stages can vary, but a basic sequence is agenda setting, policy formulation, legitimation, implementation, and evaluation.

## Actors Involved

The policy process is a complex political process in which there are many actors: elected politicians, political party leaders, pressure groups, civil servants, publicly employed professionals, judges, non-governmental organizations, international agencies, academic experts, journalists and even sometimes citizens who see themselves as the passive recipients of policy.

Web search results for query: "Market impact finance"

Links: [{"title":"Market impact - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_impact"},{"title":"Financial market impact of the COVID-19 pandemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_market_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic"},{"title":"Impact investing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_investing"},{"title":"Financial market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_market"},{"title":"Market microstructure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_microstructure"},{"title":"Capital market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_market"},{"title":"Outline of finance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_finance_topics"},{"title":"Category:Financial markets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Financial_markets"},{"title":"Money market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Money_market"},{"title":"Profit Impact of Market Strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profit_Impact_of_Market_Strategy"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **market impact in finance**:

## Definition

Market impact is the effect that a market participant has when it buys or sells an asset, specifically the extent to which the buying or selling moves the price against the buyer or seller, i.e., upward when buying and downward when selling.

## Key Characteristics

Market impact is closely related to market liquidity; in many cases the terms are synonymous.(no content)Market impact is a key consideration before any decision to move money within or between financial markets, especially for large investors. If the amount of money being moved is large (relative to the turnover of the asset(s) in question), then the market impact can be several percentage points and needs to be assessed alongside other transaction costs.

## Management Strategies

The financial institution that is seeking to manage its market impact needs to limit the pace of its activity (e.g., keeping its activity below one-third of daily turnover) so as to avoid disrupting the price.

## Measurement

Market impact cost is a measure of market liquidity that reflects the cost faced by a trader of an index or security, measured in the chosen numeraire of the market, and is how much additionally a trader must pay over the initial price due to market slippage, i.e. the cost incurred because the transaction itself changed the price of the asset.(no content)Practitioners sometimes model market impact as proportional to the square root of traded volume, an approach that is supported by research.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
